title: Before 1 October 2018, will the water ministers of Egypt, Ethiopia, and Sudan meet to resume technical negotiations over the Renaissance Dam?
preds:
http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-04/05/c_137089033.htm
KHARTOUM, April 4 (Xinhua) -- Delegations of Egypt and Ethiopia on Wednesday arrived in the Sudanese capital Khartoum to take part in a tripartite meeting regarding the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD).
Sudan's Foreign Minister Ibrahim Ghandour and Sudan's Water Resources and Electricity Minister Mutaz Mussa received the Egyptian and Ethiopian delegations participating in the meeting.
The Egyptian delegation includes Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry, Water Resources and Irrigation Minister Mohamed Abdel Atti and Acting Chief of General Intelligence Service Abbas Mustafa Kamel.
While the Ethiopian delegation includes Minister of Foreign Affairs Workneh Gebeyehu, Minister of Water, Irrigation and Electricity, Sileshi Bekele, and Deputy Chief of Security and Intelligence. https://alternativeafrika.com/2018/04/04/egypt-ethiopia-sudan-resume-negotiation-over-nile-water/
London, April 4, 2018 (AltAfrika)-Egypt, Sudan and Ethiopia are returning to the negotiation table in Khartoum over Nile water sharing quotas.

Supposedly meeting this week. But not 100% will actually happen - talks previously scheduled didn’t happen.
https://www.albawaba.com/news/egypt-ethiopia-sudan-set-discuss-controversial-dam-next-month-1102140
The meeting is set for 4-5 APR.

Leaders are discussing and the Ethiopian water dam in nearly complete. Reuters, 28.01.2018: "The Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam - now over 60 percent complete and which will churn out 6,000 MW upon completion - is centerpiece to the country’s ambitious power exporting plans." Egypt, Ethiopia and Sudan to meet on Monday for Nile dam talks, 28.01.18
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-africaunion-summit-egypt/egypt-ethiopia-and-sudan-to-meet-on-monday-for-nile-dam-talks-idUSKBN1FH0NH

Based on reading, there has been no new news reported in the United States since March 21, 2018. According to AL-Monitor it appears that Ethiopia is prepared to continue construction and filling plans regardless of Egypt's concerns about the effects it will have down river. With on going water shortages cropping up and continued abrasive behavior between Egypt and Ethiopia, I don't see either of them sitting at the table anytime soon to negotiate, just further delays. Much like we have been warned about Climate Change being a global security risk, this is likely to turn out to be another example of that. Without proper negotiations it could result in a conflict.

Due to the perceived successful of recent talks between the leaders of all three countries, I believe that technical negotiations will not only resume but be completely resolved. Due to the fact that all leaders gave themselves a one month deadline in laying out ways to break the deadlock during a recent meeting in January, by the First of October should definitely see some progress and development be resolved on this issue. I want to remain optimistic and say that due to increasingly advanced technology, all three sides on this issue can find a way to compromise and have their biggest concerns answered. The leaders have already agreed to multiple actions in meeting their one month deadline, such as annul state leadership meetings between the three countries and setting up a fund to link the three countries via railway. I overall remain quite optimistic of the developments on this issue.  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-africanunion-summit-nile/egypt-ethiopia-and-sudan-hope-to-break-nile-dam-talks-deadlock-in-one-month-idUSKBN1FI1LC

Meeting between Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Ministers of Irrigation, and the Heads of Intelligence for all 3 countries, Egypt, Sudan, and Ethiopia still scheduled for April 4-5 to discuss the Renaissance Dam project.  Recent (Feb. 2018) BBC documentary on the project and its political implications and conflicts: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F3TpyAAoFX0
"A new political order is emerging and Egypt doesn't like it." Doc cites "level of anger" created by Ethiopia not consulting Egypt before starting the project,  has created buzz whether this would be the first war over water.   Watched quite a few news reports (CGTN Africa, a network with the disclaimer that it's partly funded by Chinese gov). 
Former Water Minister for Egypt said his country is very concerned, said they have been negotiating since 2011 and that studies are inadequate and incomplete. He said to have "severe remarks" regarding the excavation and the design itself. 
Ethiopia's lead negotiator said the dam is being constructed according to international standards and there should be no reason for concern.  Egypt is also angry about construction continuing before agreements are made. Egypt wants to considerably reduce the size of the dam in order to minimize it.  The former water minister e spelled the principles for the upcoming talks, including all three countries benefiting equally, reducing harm on Egyptian water and hydro-power, reduce water loses for Egypt. There are a lot more details and technical arguments on the discussion here:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RD72UStS-yI If I understand the question correctly, the April 4-5 meeting resolves the question as it is a meeting about technical negotiations.  If anyone can confirm this, I'd appreciate it.
The water ministers are set to meet in two weeks. Unless something drastic happens, there is little to indicate that this meeting won't occur.
All parties have such a critical interest in this project that it is nearly inevitable they discuss this further and come to an agreement.

Substantially adjusting upward to 60% as Sudan has sent out invitations to both Egypt and Ethiopa to have a meeting on the dam in early April between foreign and water/irrigation ministers. Egypt has expressed a desire to solve the issue without escalation.  https://www.egypttoday.com/Article/1/45174/Egypt-receives-invitation-for-GERD-meeting-in-Khartoum&ct=ga&cd=CAEYACoUMTA3NTE5MTQwNjA3NzYyOTkyODIyHTI3MmMyZmJhOWZhYTBiY2Y6Y29tLmF1OmVuOkFV&usg=AFQjCNHRZ4obm-W7xfIB6f5qXpRrBoAwFA

Egypt, Sudan, and Ethiopia will meet April 4-5 to discuss Renaissance Dam project. Meeting will include the Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Ministers of Irrigation, and the Heads of Intelligence for all 3 countries.

Looks like about to happen in April: Sudan said on Tuesday that it would host a meeting between foreign and water ministers and heads of intelligence services form Egypt, Ethiopia and Sudan on April 4-5 regarding the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD). 
https://www.albawaba.com/news/egypt-ethiopia-sudan-set-discuss-controversial-dam-next-month-1102140

Per widsmith and hazmate - thank you. Sounds like this will be quiet during Egyptian election (no meetings or agreements until after election). After things may get ugly...  there has been postulation Darfur and Syria issues exacerbated by failed rainfall etc.  Near the end of the article, check out the % of citizens living in Nile basin. 
https://qz.com/1181318/ethiopia-egypt-sudan-and-eritrea-tensions-over-grand-ethiopian-renaissance-dam-on-nile-river/

The current Egyptian water minister is taking a hard stance on the time frame for the filling of the dam and is at this point unlikely to change his views. He also has the support of the rest of the Egyptian government. Being a national and historical issue for Egypt it is hard to see their stance changing unless the government changes their stance.
http://www.arabnews.com/node/1204921/middle-east Sisi has publicly claimed that Egypt will not attempt to destroy or damage the dam and as that would be costly for Egypt both in carrying out such an operation and in the international political costs that would follow from African states and likely the UN. Sudan is supportive of the dam and claims that Egypt is exaggerating effects on the Nile. Sudan-Egypt relations are also complicated by Sudan's accusations that Egypt is funding rebel groups in Sudanese territory.  Following accusations from Egypt of always siding with Ethiopia, Sudan withdrew its ambassador from Cairo and moved troops to their northern border region. This may effect the ability of these two states on coming to an agreement on the dam. 
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/01/sisi-egypt-war-sudan-ethiopia-180116074205823.html Successive Ethiopian governments have supported the construction of the project and are beyond the point of giving up on completion as it would be more costly for Ethiopia than finishing it. It is currently more than 60% completed. Outcome of the Egyptian presidential election may effect Egypt's stance on the dam. Forecast may have to be changed depending on the outcome, while Sisi will likely be re-elected due to lack of competitive challengers, a ministry reshuffle cannot be ruled out.
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/01/egypt-presidential-election-rendered-irrelevant-180122125426620.html If two out of the three states agree on the dam as it is and still wish to continue negotiations that's 2/3 so 66%. But with Egypt's hard stance on the Nile, -15%, currently difficult Sudan-Egypt relations, -10%, uncertainty associated with the election, -5%, and a relatively close deadline, -5%, current prediction sits at 31%.

Egypt is about to have elections, that will stop everything for a couple of months, then another couple of months for new government to settle in (even it is same people, they still need time), that leaves only 2-3 months before October. Turkey is meddling which is only annoying Egypt more. Egypt has a lot to worry about just now, I think they will not find the time to think hard about this endemic issue.
Postponement due to political uncertainty in Ethiopia. Egypt's stake in successful diplomatic influence on the filing timeline is a national issue.
Ethiopia can seek the needed technical assistance from other sources. Egypt and Sudan have too many immediate issues, esp. around security, to keep up long term displeasure.

This article seems to indicate that the ministers intended to meet recently. They've got 7 months to reschedule before the question closes. "The source said that Addis Ababa had asked the Sudanese side to postpone the meeting of the joint committee composed of ministers of foreign affairs, irrigation and intelligence chiefs from the three countries, which was supposed to be held on February 24 and 25 in Khartoum." - http://www.egyptindependent.com/egypt-did-not-receive-plans-from-ethiopia-on-filling-gerd-source/
Meeting is likely to happen but unlikely to have results.
Driven by climate change to cooperate.
On the brink of collapsed government and civil war in Ethiopia.
Almost no possibility because no one is ready to give up major share of water.
Yes, they will meet, but will they resolve the water issue?
They are consumed with them selves, not Humanity...

yes , but inconclusive. Egypt concerned about upstream dam and reduction of Nile flows. I don't see a viable river allocation as on Colorado River at this time so brinkmanship likely to play out in near term.
Looks like former PM Desalegn was a driving factor of the Dam; it remains to be seen whether the next PM will work well with Egypt or not.

I just read about this issue on the BBC.  My forecast is largely based on the high need for water issues to be solved, and my bias that the ministers in these countries will agree program needs to be made before the dam is ready to start filling.

The tripartite of ministers has met over 15 times since Sept. 2014.  Only twice did at least 6 months pass between those meetings.  The Ethiopian government has some incentive to resolve the negotiations with Egypt so it can focus on its current internal unrest.
The obvious reason: water is vital to all these polities.

technical negotiations are critical to the office of ministers of water irrigation and electricity. if they don't meet to negotiate a dam on the largest river in the region they are not doing their jobs and should be fired.
Despite the recent postponement of talks, the next Prime Minister of Ethiopia will likely prioritize GERD discussion.
Because its water on a desertical place. It is this or people shooting each other.
They will all realize the importance of maintaining water resources in these countries.

One feels compelled to remind @Captbullett and @1derer that just because something urgently needs to be done is not necessarily a basis for predicting that it will be done.    Luckily for many of us, @1derer, compromise is a well established and highly respected way of life in the US, so our decisionmakers never get involved in haggling for personal or political or other self-interested reasons, and all of our policy machinery operates smoothly and at all times in the greater public interest.  This is probably because we lack bazaars as a haggling venue.  And that's why everything is just swell here. Coming down some more, just because I'm having a bad day, so everyone else should as well.

Assuming the state of Emergency lasts the full 6 months, and that little or no progress is made in rescheduling talks during that state of Emergency, that leaves less than 2 months to to schedule and conduct talks to meet the forecast deadline. A extension of the state of emergency is quite possible, adding further delay. More likely, however, is that rescheduling will begin in earnest towards the end of the emergency with a total delay from the original schedule of roughly one year.
this is a global resource and they must meet to resolve this issue to many live and jobs are ...

They have to, water is a resource to precious for the arid area.  War would not solve the problem.  However, basic civility and strong Diplomatic haggling should find a compromise between States for the benefit of all...They know better and it's just haggling for a region known to haggle at their local Bazaars... ...

Update:  The @RenaissanceDam twitter account posted yesterday that Italian Construction Company Salini Impregilo had reportedly suspended construction activities at the dam.  This account seems to be engaged in propaganda, tweeting in favor of Egypt's position in the matter.   They also posted a tweet with a link to an article in Arabic on Feb. 19, saying that the US is offering assistance to reach agreement on renaissance Dam with Ethiopia.   A tweet from Feb. 17, linking to an Arab publication, saying that "The Sudanese Foreign Ministry announced the postponement of the tripartite meeting on the Ethiopian Renaissance Dam, scheduled to be held in Khartoum next week."   Other tweets from February on their TL read:  
Source: #Egypt closely monitoring political development of #Ethiopia after prime minister hailemariam resigned.
"HANI RUSSLAN: #Ethiopian Prime Minister's resignation makes the Renaissance  Dam negotiations more flexible #Egypt"  
Expert: #Egypt must exploit the political situation in #Ethiopia and provide support and support to the Ethiopian people. Egypt's support for the Ethiopian people now has political gains that no one would expect. #Sudan The key now seems to be watching the political situation in Ethiopia.  After the prime minister resignation last week, a state of emergency was declared and continues. A succession battle to replace him has begun, there are mass protests.

Heading way up because the meeting that was scheduled for this weekend (see article) has been delayed but I didn't get the impression it wasn't going to happen. Seems more likely that its because of internal Ethiopian political turmoil and not because they are trying to avoid the meeting. Suggests it will happen sometime in the next eight months at least. http://www.egyptindependent.com/ethiopia-postpones-renaissance-dam-meeting-amid-domestic-tension-egypt-fm/

International actors with interests in the region (China and others)  will force their hand in a resolution. 
It is against their interests that things escalate in the region.

Only 9% "yes" for the following reasons:
1) The dam will adversly impact approximately 100 million Egyptians by desrupting the natural flow of water and will negativiely impact the local agricultural sector.
2) Depite Sisi having a seemingly more lax stance on Nile water rights, he has publicaly condemned the dam and states that "Egypt does not want to go to war with its neighbors."
3) Turkey is gradually getting involved by attempting to establish a third base abroad in Sudan. Egypt claims that Erdogan is a Muslim Brotherhood sympathizer (jeopardizing constructive political dialogue between Sudan and Egypt).
4) Ethiopia and Sudan seem unwavering in their pursuits.
I make this forecast because while Egypt, Ethiopia, and Sudan are in a disagreement, something must be done, and Egypt and Sudan know it. The case is not closed.

Whether they are the technical water ministers or emerging leaders within those nations, the answer is yes.

This issue seems salient enough that the impacts of the negotiated subject will begin to make palpable impacts.
Took current estimate as a base rate, but lowered it a bit since Ethiopian prime minister stepped down a few days ago.
Regime change and resulting instability in Ethiopia will make it less likely that any serious negotiations will take place.
Meetings have been taking place at higher levels.  It is probably time to address things at lower, more practical leveels.
Water matters but it will take a crisis to force a solution.
South Africa issues with water shortage will drive leaders to become more concerned about water issues.
They have let multiple le times over the past few years AND none of the countries can afford to a)ignore the problem of )b go to war.
Reducing to 33%. Per commentary from my peers, little incentive to truly negotiate. Water is an important issue in this part of world and tied to many other items - which they can’t agree on.
https://www.wsj.com/articles/ethiopian-leader-to-step-down-in-wake-of-unrest-1518707206 Doesn't really change anything -- meeting can still not go ahead

If Ethiopia's plans continue forward without interruption, eventually the three must meet in order to address water rights or risk open conflict. While I do not think the meeting will happen in February, as construction progresses eventually a meeting must take place, but maybe not before 1 October 2018.

Multiple news sources reported in late January a planned February meeting between the water ministers of Egypt, Ethiopia and Sudan.  Rather than the meeting between the three nations to discuss technical issues related to the dam, Egypt and Sudan conducted a bilateral meet between their foreign ministers and high level intelligence officials to speak about international and regional issues of mutual concern.  The dam belongs to Ethiopia and they were excluded from the meeting.  Egypt and Sudan will have their major water source, the Nile river, compromised when the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam is completed.  No opening day for the dam has been announced and it is estimated to be about 60% complete.  Egypt and Sudan will likely do whatever they can to make sure the dam never opens or the completion is slowed as much as possible.  Treaties and promises are well meaning in that area of the world, but water is in short supply for all three countries.  It appears as if Egypt and Sudan have decided to ally and oppose Ethiopia's dam rather than attempt diplomacy.  Seems like the correct strategy.  I wouldn't trust any of the three countries involved in any way.

The Nile is the lifeblood of Egypt.  The Ethiopian dam will impact the water flow downstream.  President el-Sisi of Egypt doesn't want to face more domestic unrest if the reduction of water impacts harvests and raises food prices.  There is also the possibility that Egypt could launch an airstrike to destroy the dam.
Leaders have called for water ministers to meet but I think there are too many spoilers for a meeting to actually take place between all three.

The ministers have several reasons to promote the discussions.  I think as the middle east becomes more unstable, they will want the water issue resolved to cement the process into a signed document one way or another

Although Cairo has softened to consider the Renaissance Dam, with the 2015 study on its effects, it remains adamant that Egypt should control the biggest share of the Nile. Egypt has also accused Sudan of being on the side of Ethiopia and has suggested excluding Khartoum from the negotiations. This is further exacerbated by accusations of Sudan increasing Turkey's and the Muslim Brotherhood's presence in the region, which Egypt is adamant against.
They are not able to do strong negotiations with a clear target. They fritter away it.

Seems like Sudan and Ethiopia are prepared to go ahead with build with or without Egypt. I'm assuming a technical meeting between two out of three countries won't count towards resolving this as 'yes' http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/02/nile-dam-dispute-troops-mass-sudan-eritrea-border-180202150903811.html
They must get a solution for all.
The Nile River is the key.
Need for power.  Economic growth will drive them to resolve issues
Too much turmoil in the region for that to happen right now.
It's more important as it meets completion.

For no better reason, researched or otherwise, the Sudan has no obvious reason to participate. If I was Sudan, I would stem (not stop) the flow of the river for both hydroelectric power and irrigation. This would affect flows downstream in Ethiopia. The Ethiopian project will be derailed by such moves upstream by Sudan all with Egypt and its' traditional reliance on the free flow of the river being cut off - really? Will this lack of cooperation lead to potential conflict in the region, Yes!

Baseline probability 33% for each of three countries:
- Populations: Egypt 96m, Ethiopia 104m, Sudan 40m
- without access to electricity, without improved water: Egypt 0.4%, .07; Ethiopia 76.7, 48.5; Sudan 45%
- current allotment under article 5 (signed in 1959 without input from Ethiopia) declaration of principals Egypt 55.5 Ethiopia and Sudan 18.5 each 66% with Sudan and Ethiopia pushing, and Egypt stalling
-10% reduction for Egypt’s long-standing inhabitation of Nile Valley and Delta (Article 2 “To cooperate in understanding upstream and downstream water needs in its various aspects”) works against Ethiopia claim of a bigger share
-10% because it seems that Ethiopia doesn’t want to blatantly challenge the 2015 agreement. It could just start to build as it contributes most to total volume of Nile water.
-10% for question deadline which is quickly approaching Notes:
48% of Ethiopians without access to improved water (Unesco) and forging relations, including defence, with Qatar.  "The Ethiopian Prime Minister visited Qatar on Nov. 13 and 14 [2017] and signed several agreements to improve cooperation between the two countries, among which was an agreement on defense cooperation. This visit came seven months after the visit of the Emir of Qatar, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al-Thani, to the Ethiopian capital Addis Ababa. During his visit to Qatar, Ethiopia’s PM denied receiving funds from Qatar for GERD and stressed that the mega-project was “self-financed." https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/ru/contents/articles/originals/2016/01/saudi-investments-agriculture-sudan-egypt-fears-water-nile.html http://www.arabnews.com/node/1195321/middle-east www.omicsonline.org/open-access/agreement-on-declaration-of-principles-on-the-grand-ethiopianrenaissance-dam-project-a-reaffirmation-of-the-1929-and-1959agreement-2151-6200-1000170.php?aid=71460#1 writer seems pro-Ethiopia
Egypt has nothing bringing it to the negotiation table. Without incentives, they will veto it by inaction

Egypt needs to coordinate the working of their damn with the the filling of the Renaissance Damn. If the damn is still on track to be completed in October, it seems plausible that Eygpt will not have a choice but to negotiate the technical operations of the damn. The 15% no is if the Damn is delayed or they don't bring Sudan back to the negotiations.

Egypt, Ethiopia and Sudan hope to break Nile dam talks deadlock in one month

-Egypt and Sudan wary about encroachment of water share
- Egypt probably has the might to stop it,or effect its progress

They’ll meet - but that doesn’t mean progress. Like Darfur and Syria, water scarcity/climate could lead to something worse. So they might as well meet, expense some nice food and hang with their homies from other countries while each jockeys for position. They are too narrow minded (and nationalistic) to realize this isn’t zero sum. But chances of them truly working together for common good? About zero percent (rounded up)
Thanks @cdob63 -- that makes alot of sense. It sounds so complicated on the waterfront that they probably would have to involve the tech folks... swimming in honey.
Percentage is higher based on the fact that the question only requires a meeting of the 3 countries rather than an agreement.
No one there ever agrees on anything

The global climate warming crisis and impending lack of potable water in Africa and elsewhere is going to keep the Renaissance Dam at the top of governmental and environmental priority lists. Although the political agendas of each country will continue to conflict with each other, the question of water availability will be on the minds of all concerned.
Egypt and Sudan and Ethiopia should find a commun background to resolve the dispute over the dam

War is extremely unlikely, as Egypt and Ethiopia fought over water two centuries ago. Egypt knows its demand of 90% of the Nile is unreasonable, but will use this position to leverage a higher percentage than its current 65%. Barring highly unlikely war, both sides need to talk to get what they want.

Technical meetings will not resume until political side is negotiated.  There are many political issues in the area and one can just assume a lot will be used as leverage to negotiate for the three countries (https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/fr/contents/articles/originals/2016/02/egypt-interview-orabi-sudan-ethiopia-renaissance-dam.html ) Egypt seems to have the political and economical edge, and it's also the one opposed to the project. 
Egypt was opposed to the idea of the dam (former president, Mohammed Morsi, went as far as proposing military action against Ethiopia if project moved forward, saying the dam would disrupt the flow of the Nile to Egypt's 100 million population, potentially crippling its agricultural sector and industries).  The current president, al-Sisi, said in mid January that Egypt wasn't prepared to go to war with "brethren nations."  Was he signaling that he's again ready to negotiate?  Or is it a subtle threat?   "During the filling of the reservoir, experts say the Nile’s freshwater flow to Egypt may be cut by 25%. This will also compound the other problems threatening the Nile including climate change, population boom, urban sprawl, besides rising sea levels that lead to saltwater intrusion." Not clear how Sudan benefits, from this article in Sudan Tribune,   http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article64431 but Sudan backs the project. The country's foreign minister said in December there was no real conflict between the nations but that it all had been made up by the media.  These are some interesting recent articles on the many issues involved:
http://foreignpolicy.com/2018/01/11/egypt-sudan-spat-muddies-prospects-for-deal-on-big-nile-dam-renaissance-gerd-ethiopia-sisi-turkey/

Talks are stalled over how to deal with the impact of a $5 billion dam that could threaten Egypt’s lifeblood.
BY KEITH JOHNSON | JANUARY 11, 2018, 5:30 PM
http://foreignpolicy.com/2018/01/11/egypt-sudan-spat-muddies-prospects-for-deal-on-big-nile-dam-renaissance-gerd-ethiopia-sisi-turkey/
This article detailing the many conflicts in the region is specially informative

This is escalating, so I doubt it ends in "technical" talks any time soon. Ethiopia's dam isn't even remotely good for Egypt or Sudan, arguably more powerful players despite being at Ethiopia's mercy in this power-play for control of the Nile. Over 100 million people could be impacted in Egypt alone, as well as agriculture, and it looks like technical discussions have already more-or-less failed due to the interests of Egypt in particular being completely at odds with a country unwilling to make concessions. This is escalating to another level, so negotiations between water ministers seems less likely, at least in the short-term.  By October?  Who knows.  A lot can happen.  It's an issue important to everyone involved, and this thing has been stalling for years... So, as this comes to a head, will it result in a breakthrough or not?  My guess is "not," unfortunately. Ethiopia is now simply pushing ahead to build the (dam) thing one way or another; nonetheless, "Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi told reporters who asked whether the crisis was resolved that 'there is no crisis . . .'" (alarabiya.net)  While this strongly suggests that talk is not off the table, Egypt simply can't let this go through while trying its best to play by international rules. This thing has gotten wayyy too complicated. Neither stalling nor negotiation has worked, and it sounds like the politics are progressing way beyond "water ministers" talking about the details at this point. The Ethiopians will build their dam, and Egypt will try playing different cards now, because the impasse has been met. Article Seeming to Imply this Ends w/ Talks: 
http://english.alarabiya.net/en/features/2018/02/06/Egypt-and-Ethiopia-between-deadlock-and-breakthrough-over-Nile-dam.html Article Seeming to Suggest this Ends in Possible War:
https://qz.com/1181318/ethiopia-egypt-sudan-and-eritrea-tensions-over-grand-ethiopian-renaissance-dam-on-nile-river/

@Intriligator: Political dynamics among all actors, including Turkey’s role in Sudan has exacerbated tensions, with Egypt calling for the elimination of Sudan from its role in this project.  While the negotiation dynamics center on electricity, water, its negative externalities on Egypt’s water systems, interactions among states,  their disputes evitably continue.  Concerns regarding the role of the Muslim Brotherhood in the region has intensified; Egypt’s concerns and tensions with Khartoum and Turkey and their relationship with the Brotherhood.   Negotiations amid these controversies will inevitably occur at a rate slower than would be expected.  However the IFP calls for a: whether resumption of technical talks and not a resolution of conflict parameters.  the conflict parameters are relevant to computations, constraints and externalities and its relationship to dispute resolution.  The conditional probability of the occurrence of technical talks given the degree of change found during dispute resolution among all parties will determine its outcome; Posterior probabilities, and Prior knowledge along with private information among all state and non-state actors.   P(A|B) = P(B|A) P(A) / P(B) subject to political constraints that produce negative or positive externalities for all states directly or indirectly involved.  Negative externalities are weighted to reduce likelihood of participation of states while positive externalities are weighted to increase participation. Weighted negative and positive externalities are determined for the initiator(s) only.
Talk is cheap, and there is no obvious reason for talks not to proceed.  Doubtless I am missing something.

According to Reuters, the leadership in these countries has directed their water ministers to come up with a report in the next month (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-africanunion-summit-nile/egypt-ethiopia-and-sudan-hope-to-break-nile-dam-talks-deadlock-in-one-month-idUSKBN1FI1LC). So I would assume that they would meet at some point to discuss. However, I'm unsure if they would restart "technical negotiations" (or even what that entails), so I'm hedging until I learn more.
